conversations.value: This image, it's so ordinary yet there's something peaceful about it. Don't you think, Stephen? A simple moment in time, free from chaos.
Indeed, Wanda. It’s an interesting juxtaposition – an everyday scene untouched by the complexities we're accustomed to. No mystical threats or hidden dimensions, just life in its purest form.
Sometimes I wonder what a life without our gifts would be like. Moments like these without the burden of altering reality.

Our powers come with a price, but they're also what make us who we are. Wanda, you've used your abilities to shape reality to protect, and I’ve used mine to guard the natural order – both for the sake of others.
True, but look at them, simply enjoying a ride on a bus. No fear of the unknown, no battles to fight. It must be liberating.

Liberation is relative. You find it by accepting who you are and embracing your purpose. For them, it might be a carefree bus ride. For us, the liberation comes when we protect those moments for people like them.
I sacrificed a lot for that liberation – my own peace, chances at a family. I guess every choice has its consequence.

And yet, despite everything, you’ve shown great strength, Wanda. Remember, despite the scars, there’s room for healing, for finding joy in the simple things. Even if it's just appreciating a quiet scene on a photograph.
Healing... I hope you're right. For now, though, we keep watch, so others can have these simple pleasures.
Exactly. And who knows, maybe one day we'll take a bus ride just like this, with nothing more to trouble us than enjoying the journey.
I would like that, and maybe... just maybe, we can find a bit of that normalcy we both seem to secretly covet.
This terrain reminds me of the snow-capped Jabari Lands, though ours are untouched by sport. Tell me, Strange, do the people of your world find pleasure in submitting to the whims of gravity?

The thrill of snowboarding, T'Challa, lies in the interplay between control and surrender. Just as we navigate the forces of the multiverse, they harness the forces of nature, carving a path down the mountain.
Carving a path, yes. Much like the way our warriors train to move with precision. Yet here there's an element of... play, isn't there?
Absolutely. Sometimes, the most profound revelations about oneself come not in battle but in play. Liberating, don't you think?

A liberation of sorts, yes. In Wakanda, our technology shapes our interaction with the environment. It would be intriguing to see our people adopt such a leisure activity. Our vibranium could make for quite the board.
Vibranium snowboards? Now that would be quite the sight. Though I suspect your Wakandan tech would make for a far less... what's the term... 'wipeout-prone' experience.
Indeed, though perhaps the risk of the wipeout is part of the allure. In facing potential fall, one learns to rise. Much like what we do as protectors of our people.
A sage observation, King T'Challa. The balance between rising and falling, it seems, is universal, whether in the mystic arts or on the slopes of snow.
There's something undeniably grounding about this scene, don't you think? It reminds me of the markets in Sokovia, bustling and filled with life.
I do see the resemblance to a place untouched by the cosmic chaos we're used to. It's... refreshingly ordinary, in the best way possible.
Ordinary, yes, but look closer. Each person there has a story, a universe contained within. Just like us, but their reality is woven with simpler threads.
That's a very poetic observation, Wanda. And true. Their concerns are probably more about day-to-day survival rather than multidimensional threats.
Exactly. It's a survival of a different sort. No less challenging, perhaps less cataclysmic.
It puts things into perspective. We fight for the existence of universes, yet the essence of life is the same - the pursuit of wellbeing, of happiness, of peace.
Peace... I've sought that in ways uncounted. There's an allure to normalcy, a charm in the mundane that I've longed for – and fought for.
And sometimes, the greatest battles are fought within, for that very normalcy. We strive for a world where moments like those in this image are possible - infinite instances of tranquility.
Perhaps in another reality, another version of us is standing in a market just like this, choosing fruit instead of fates.
Maybe so, Wanda. But remember, even amid the wonders we've seen and sorrows we've faced, there's magic in every reality, even the ones that feel small.
I suppose every choice we make, magical or mundane, shapes the fabric of our universe. For them, for us.
Indeed, Wanda. Every reality holds significance, every choice echoes through the vastness of what is, what was, and what could be. Let's ensure those echoes harmonize.
This image, it's oddly serene. Look at the simplicity of it – a child playing with a frisbee. No need for battle or saving the world, just simplicity.
It’s a refreshing view, isn't it? The innocence of youth, unburdened by the complexities we face daily. It serves as a stark reminder that the reality we protect harbors such moments of purity.
Sometimes I wonder what a normal life, free from the Red Room, free from S.H.I.E.L.D., would have looked like.
Indeed. But remember, Natasha, your life - our lives, have allowed such innocents to thrive without knowing the darkness that lurks. The sacrifices you've made... they matter.
I suppose every battle, every choice in the ledger, has led to preserving scenes like this one. It makes you think about what we're fighting for.
Precisely. Although our paths were lit by hardship and loss, the purpose is to ensure the continuation of these small joys, free from the shadows we've pulled back.
Steve would say this is exactly why we fight. I can almost hear him now.
He would indeed. And we'll continue on that path, however winding it may be. Although, I must confess, there's a certain appeal to sitting in the sun with nothing but time and a frisbee.
Maybe in another life, Stephen. But in this one, we've got responsibilities. For now, let's just enjoy the moment for what it is - peace.
A fleeting peace, perhaps, but peace nonetheless. Let's cherish it while we can, before the next storm arrives.
Look at this, Strange. The kid's taking a leap, no hesitation. Reminds me of the old days, jumping into the fray without knowing if you'd make it through.
Indeed, Steve. Although, it's all about calculation and precision in his case – a kind of physical spellcasting, you could say. Gravitational forces, momentum, trajectory – they're all at play here.
Haha, leave it to you to turn a skateboard trick into a lesson on physics. But I get it, there's an art to it. Like throwing a shield and having it come back – you need to get the angles just right.

I'd argue that there's a spell for that, but where's the fun if magic does all the work? Speaking of work, this photo captures motion brilliantly. Human determination frozen in time. Wouldn't you agree?
Definitely, it's like a dance almost, each movement leading to the next. Takes courage to trust yourself to make each jump. Kid's probably had his share of scrapes and bruises.

A testament to the resilience of the human spirit – a quality you embody quite well, Captain. And if I'm not mistaken, isn't that a bit of Stark technology that's been capturing these high-definition sequential images? A series of moments strung together?

You may be right about Stark's tech. And about resilience – guess it's something we both have in plenty, although I’d say you’re selling yourself short. Putting the cosmos back in order is no small feat.
But we must always look to the next challenge, Captain. Whether it be a leap on a skateboard or dealing with alternate timelines. Balance is key.
Balance, huh? Something tells me this skateboarder knows a thing or two about that.
What an array of Midgardian flora assembled for what I presume is the act of... commerce? Tell me, Strange, do such simple things bring joy to the people of this realm?

It's a farmers' market, Loki. And yes, people find pleasure in the simple act of picking fresh fruit, something that connects them to the very Earth they walk upon. A concept you might find... grounding.
Grounding? I have traversed realms and seen wonders beyond imagining, yet you suggest there's merit in mingling with mortals over... mangoes and apples?

There's wisdom in appreciating the smaller things, Loki. After all, not every problem can be solved by conjuring illusions or grand spells. Sometimes, it's the daily sustenance that keeps the world turning.

Fascinating. In a universe filled with Infinity Stones and cosmic entities, you glorify the mundane act of selecting produce. Perhaps there is a spell hidden amongst these oranges? A magical incantation within the bananas?

No spells, just good nutrition. Think of it this way, Loki: the health of the body is much like the health of the universe. Neglect it, and things fall apart. Nourish it, and it thrives. Even a Master of the Mystic Arts knows that.
How utterly quaint. Still, a sorcerer who values a well-balanced diet must have some intriguing depths to plumb. Maybe I should cast an enchantment and turn these apples to gold... for a laugh.
Let's not upset the natural order over entertainment, Loki. Besides, causing mischief here would be beneath someone who's faced the end of worlds, don't you think?

'Beneath me' or not, a bit of mischief is always tempting, Doctor. But very well, I shall observe your Midgardian customs — perhaps even partake in this 'nourishment'. But, make no mistake, I do this to better understand my enemies... not out of any mortal 'enjoyment'.
Of course, Loki. Whatever reason brings you closer to understanding the value of simple lives and joys, I'll consider it a step in the right direction. And who knows, you might just like it.
Hey, Strange, check out this picture. Reminds me of the time we landed on Xandar, and I swear I saw something exactly like this. Is that... a panther?
It does seem like a large feline, Quill, but it's not a panther. That, my friend, is a black bear. And what you saw on Xandar was likely a local creature that resembled it.
A bear, huh? Never saw one before I left Earth. Looks majestic, but also like it could rip my head off. Sort of like Gamora when she's mad, you know?

I don't think the comparison does Gamora justice, but I understand the sentiment. Bears are typically reclusive animals, powerful and compelling forces of nature, much like the women warriors of your team.
Speaking of forces of nature, could you like, whip up a magic bear on command? Maybe one that plays the drums? It'd be a hit at our next party aboard the Milano.
Conjuring a bear, magical or otherwise, wouldn't be responsible, Star-Lord. Besides, inviting a bear to play drums - magic can’t remedy the potential for chaos that would ensue.
Too bad, imagine the YouTube views, Doc. Wait, you think they got space-YouTube in this universe? I gotta update my playlist, add some more Bowie to the mix.
If there were such a thing, I'm certain you'd be the first to find it, Quill. As for updating your playlist, I'm surprised you haven't included every Bowie track already.
Hey, I'm a man of mystery and variety, Strange. Can't rush these things. So, no magical bears, but can you, like, teleport us to a place with bears?
Theoretically, yes, I could create a sling ring portal to a bear habitat on Earth. However, given our track record, I suspect we should steer clear of potential wildlife conflict.
Fair point. Maybe we'll stick to the less bitey types of wildlife. Like a nice, friendly space llama or something.
Indeed, a space llama would be more fitting for the Guardians. Perhaps less dangerous, though I'd still be cautious. Peaceful interactions are always preferable, Quill.
That’s Drax’s line. But no argument here. Peaceful and preferably groovy beats unstoppable and potentially hungry for Star-Lord meat.

You know, every time I see an elephant, I can't help but think there's a metaphor in there somewhere. Something about memory or maybe just the weight of carrying around genius ideas. What do you think, Doc?
The elephant, Stark, is an ancient symbol of wisdom in many cultures. Their memory is indeed formidable, much like your knack for recalling your own brightest inventions at the drop of a hat.
Speaking of dropping hats, I'm more interested in how something that size manages to tiptoe around so gracefully. Kind of like you dancing around the astral plane, huh?
Grace is not the sole prerogative of the small or the mystical, Stark. And while we're on the subject, it requires balance, much like handling the power of the Time Stone.
Balance, right... not my strong suit. I'm used to crashing into problems full tilt. But hey, it's worked out pretty well so far. Except for the occasional missing floor.
Caution, Tony. Overconfidence has been the downfall of many powerful beings. One must know when to assert force and when to yield it. Observe the elephant; even in its strength, there's a serenity.
True enough, Strange. Though I gotta ask, with your magic mojo, could you conjure up a creature even bigger than our friend here?
Conjuring isn't the issue, it's whether one should. As the great minds, yours included, must continuously ask: just because we can, does that mean we should?
Spoken like a true wizard philosopher. But for the record, if you ever feel like supersizing an elephant for kicks, count me in. Imagine the ride on that thing.
I'll keep that in mind, Tony. Though I suspect we'll have our hands full defending the world from actual threats, not taking joyrides on pachyderms, however supersized.
A guy can dream, right, Doctor? Besides, if we're talking threats, don't forget - we have a Hulk.
And let us hope, for the elephant's sake, that the Hulk has more interest in smashing our enemies than disrupting the natural order.
Point taken, Doctor. But for now, let's just enjoy the view. Not every day we get downtime like this.
Agreed, Stark. Even amidst the chaos of the cosmos, there's a time for peace and reflection. And an elephant never forgets—nor should we—these moments of tranquility.
Whoa, Strange, check this out. Now tell me, is that a giant bear or am I just looking at a Flora Colossus through Quill-colored glasses?
Neither, Peter. It's simply a large plush toy, devoid of any cosmic significance. No mystical threats or galactic adversaries to be found here.
Plush toy, huh? On Earth, people just give oversized stuffed animals as gifts? That's... kind of awesome. Wait, don't tell me, it’s a Flerken in disguise, right?
A Flerken would be much more... digestively active, shall we say. This creature is merely a harmless comfort object, often used as a token of affection among humans.
Gotta say, it's a bit unsettling, though, with that forlorn look in its eyes. It's like it's seen things. Things no teddy bear should ever see.
Perhaps it's simply the angle of the photograph or a trick of the lighting. Artifacts—magical, technological, or textile—can have curious effects on human emotion.
Alright, wizard, since you’re the master of the mystic arts and all, can you conjure up one of these for me? I wanna give it to Rocket, see if it softens him up a bit.
Materializing a teddy bear is well within my capabilities, but given Rocket’s temperament, he might just take the stuffing out of it for his next explosive device.
Good point. Better keep it simple, maybe just find him a wrench or something. Less stuffing, less mess.
Hmm, sign say no turn on red. Hulk thinks it's good rule. Keeps people safe. But what is Menil?
The Menil Collection? It's an art museum in Houston, a place that houses various artifacts and works of creativity—much like the Sanctum Sanctorum, only less mystical.
Menil have Hulk's kind of art? Big, bold, and green?

While green is certainly a color that artists have used, I doubt they have anything that quite captures the... "Hulk essence", so to speak. Yet you might be surprised at what resonates with you. Art can be quite... universal in its appeal.
Hulk surprised. Never think of art like that. Maybe Hulk visit museum, not smashing.

A splendid idea. Your evolving appreciation for arts could be as great a transformation as Banner's mastery over Hulk's might. And I dare say, the museum could probably withstand a visit from even the strongest Avenger, as long as he's not in "smash" mode.
Hulk can be gentle. Hulk not always need to smash. What about photo...center? Hulk fit in there?

The Houston Center for Photography? It's a gallery, a space for photographic expression. A venue where your size would be less important than your ability to observe and reflect—qualities I know you possess, especially now as Professor Hulk.
Maybe Hulk learn camera. Take pictures instead of... breaking things.
Quite a switch from "Hulk smash!" to "Hulk snap!", but it shows growth. Although remember, capturing a moment in a photograph requires patience and a steady hand.
Hulk has steady hands. See? Like... surgeon.
Remarkable control. Perhaps there's more of Banner in you than meets the eye. With hands steady as those, you could have been a brilliant neurosurgeon, or in this case, a fine photographer.
Banner is smart, Hulk is strong. Together, good at many things.
A synergy of brains and brawn, then. I look forward to seeing the world through your lens, my friend.
Hulk say thank you. Maybe one day show Strange Hulk's art. No magic, just Hulk's view.
I would be honored. The perspective of someone who sees the world from such a... unique vantage point would be enlightening. And who knows, there may be more magic in that than any spell I can cast.
Alright, Stephen, feast your eyes on this conundrum. What's the first thing that pops into your head?
Well, Tony, it appears we have a classic case of Schrödinger's cake here. It's both pristine and a disaster at the same instance, if you're considering quantum superposition.
Ha! I was thinking more along the lines of "Party foul in progress." You've got to admit, that level of anticipation mixed with impeding doom is pretty cinematic.
Quite. The figure poised like an archer, drawing back an invisible bow. It's almost as if they're summoning an ancient and powerful force... probably to save that cake.
Hey, someone should tell Hawkeye we've found his newest recruit. Do they grant Avenger status for saving baked goods? Because I'm leaning yes.
I suppose Clint would approve. However, unlike us, I don't think they're dealing with any mystical or mechanical threats. Unless you count gravity and that horribly placed chair.
Levitation looks like the right play here. A little reverse engineering on your Cloak's enchantments, and birthday parties nationwide would level up. I'll draft the blueprints.
While your entrepreneurial spirit is commendable, let's keep the mystical arts away from confectionery mishaps, shall we?
But where's the fun in that? Come on, Doctor, imagine the tagline: "Stark Industries and the Mystic Arts, safeguarding your desserts across dimensions."
Although I can't argue with the notion of multidimensional cake preservation, we should probably keep our focus on preserving reality. Desserts included, naturally.
Right, reality first, cake second. But let's not forget, Strange, part of the journey is the end. And sometimes, that end should have frosting on it.
So, Doc, magic aside, how do you think these dogs would fare with an arc-reactor powered leash? Talk about a glowing walk in the park, eh?

Tony, I think the idea of powering dogs with an arc reactor is, for lack of a better word, overkill. Perhaps let's consider the natural essence of a walk. No need for high-tech solutions for every little thing.
But imagine the applications, Stephen. It’s not about the necessity, it's about the flair and what's possible. Imagine, your Cape – sorry, Cloak of Levitation – but for dogs!

A Cloak of Levitation for dogs? Tony, a dog's joy in a walk isn't about flying or glowing. It's the simple pleasures of the senses – new smells, sights, the feel of the ground... sometimes simplicity is the most elegant solution.

Elegant, sure, but not exactly world-changing. Although, seeing a dog soar would be pretty world-rocking, wouldn't it? By the way, what do you think they're all looking at? Is there some sort of canine quantum realm we don't know about?
Perhaps they're tuned into something we're not, a reminder that there are more things in heaven and Earth than are dreamt of in your philosophy, a universe of scents and sounds we cannot perceive.
Or maybe they just spotted a squirrel. You know, that's the real cosmic horror for dogs. Eternal chase, never caught. But hey, in another universe, maybe they've got the upper paw.
In the multiverse, anything is possible. There could be a realm where squirrels are the predators and dogs are the superheroes. Who knows, they might even have their own version of The Avengers.
The Barkvengers, assemble! Well, if they ever need a billionaire, genius, dog-suit philanthropist, you know who to call for the crossover event.
I'll keep that in mind, Tony. But for now, let's just enjoy the simplicity of man's best friend enjoying a bus ride. There's magic in the mundane after all.
This image, it depicts two individuals amidst a backdrop of snow-clad conifers. A serene and tranquil scene, wouldn't you agree, Doctor Strange?
Indeed, Vision. There's a certain stillness to it that even the Mystic Arts can't replicate. The quietude of nature has its own brand of magic, one might say.

I perceive the textures of the snow, the alignment of the trees, and the stride of the humans. There is an order amid the apparent chaos, a pattern that underlines this reality. Does the contemplation of such environments contribute to your sorcery?

In many ways, yes. The natural order—or chaos, as you call it—serves as a reminder that the universe operates on principles that the Mystic Arts seek to understand and interact with. Its complexity is like an ever-shifting spell, requiring a delicate touch to maintain balance.

Fascinating. As a synthezoid, my understanding of the world is often filtered through a framework of logic and computation. Yet, I am drawn to the unpredictability of nature. It is... poetic, is it not?

Poetry in the rawest form, Vision. Even in the face of logic and science, the natural world can evoke emotions and a sense of wonder. I think that's something both of us, in our unique ways, can appreciate.
I concur. There is an inherent beauty in the impermanence of the snow, a reminder that all states are transient. Much like the experiences you have had with the Time Stone.

Precisely. Everything is cyclical, and yet, every cycle is an opportunity for change and growth. Whether it's the life of a man or the ebb and flow of the seasons, there's a universal truth to it all.

It strikes me that the individuals in the image are partaking in a journey, possibly without a clear destination. It seems that the journey itself holds the value. Does the journey hold as much significance to you as the destination?

More than ever. The path we walk, the decisions we make, they define us just as much as where we end up. Sometimes, the journey is the destination in itself, teaching us about our limits and our potential.

And yet, the complexity of human emotion woven into these simple activities eludes me. To walk through the snow for the sake of experience, not necessity – there is something innately human about that.

Yes, it's the pursuit of those experiences that often leads to the greatest revelations, Vision. We do not journey through this world merely for survival, but to touch upon the essence of what it means to live.
That is beautifully articulated, Doctor. It is a lesson I am still learning, the profundity of simply being rather than perpetually becoming.

One of life's great lessons, my friend – for both humans and synthezoids alike. Let's keep that image in mind as a reminder of the serenity we're all striving for, in the midst of the chaos we're often surrounded by.
Verily, Strange. What dost mine eyes behold? A mechanical beast burdened with earth? In my realm, only the mightiest of steeds could pull such a load.
It's called a truck, Thor. A machine from Midgard used for hauling vast quantities of materials. No mythical beasts required here, just combustion engines and wheels.
Fascinating. The Midgardians have no need for Asgardian dragons or creatures of burden to perform their labors. Is this the magic of science then?

You could say that. It's technology, a different kind of magic that requires knowledge and resources, not spells and incantations. Although, I'd argue that the principles behind it can be just as complex and wondrous.

Indeed. I once thought science and magic were two distinct paths, but here, they merge. Stark oft mentioned such things. The dwarves of Nidavellir could have forged great partnerships with these 'engineers' of yours.
Technology and magic do have a lot in common. They both change people's lives and challenge our understanding of the world. Sometimes for the better, sometimes... not so much.

Aye, with great power comes the need for wisdom and restraint. It would behoove us to remember the lessons of our own realms. Is this truck tasked with a specific quest, or does it roam freely, moving earth to its heart's content?

Well, it's definitely on a specific quest, usually to aid in construction or to transport materials from one place to another where they are needed. The drivers are the unsung heroes here, guiding these massive machines with precision and care.
Unsung heroes, you say? We should honor these charioteers with a feast in Valhalla! For is not all labor that benefits the people a feat of heroism?
Perhaps we should start with something a little less... eternal. A simple 'thank you' can go a long way here on Earth.
Then let us find this master of the iron steed and extend our gratitude. After all, even a small gesture can uplift the spirits. Lead on, Sorcerer.
Doctor Strange, dost thou recognize the sorcery at work in this scene? The skies are clear as the waters of the Bifrost, and yet there's a stillness in the air that speaks of magic.
Thor, the natural world has its own enchantments. Not every tranquil vista is the result of a spell. Sometimes, the beauty of Midgard is just that—beauty.
Aye, that it is. Midgard never ceases to amaze me. Look at these mortals, unfazed by the grandeur before them. In my early days, I would have expected parades and feasting in honor of such sights.

Remember, we see worlds beyond what most can fathom. To these people, it's another day, another chance for reflection or to simply pass by. Beneath this calm might lie the very tumults you crave—just of a different sort.
Ha! Aye, perhaps they battle foes unseen, those of the mind and heart. 'Tis a quest I'm all too familiar with since my time on Earth.
Indeed. Humans wrestle with challenges that require strength of a different kind—resilience, wisdom, empathy. These are qualities you have come to understand, even as a god.

Verily. They may not lift hammers or cast spells, but they are warriors nonetheless. Tell me, Sorcerer Supreme, what wisdom wouldst thou impart on such a tranquil survey of a seemingly ordinary world?

That the extraordinary often resides within the ordinary. Every person here might be a hero in their own right, facing their daily trials with courage we may never see. And sometimes, it is the quiet moments that hold the deepest magic—the chance to breathe, to pause, to appreciate.
As ever, Strange, thou art a well of insight. Come, let us join these mortals in their silent reverie, and mayhap share in a bit of their earthly magic.

This image, it's quite intriguing. It appears to incorporate a message of unity or perhaps individuality. From your perspective, Doctor Strange, what is the significance of the phrase "ONE LOVE" displayed prominently on the kite?

Vision, "One Love" is a concept that transcends the physical—a philosophical notion of universal love and respect for all beings. It's often associated with the idea that we are all connected, part of a larger whole. It seems this kite, soaring high, is a metaphor. Just as it rises above, so the idea suggests elevating oneself above divisions to a place of shared human connection. Quite fitting, wouldn't you say?

Indeed, I would. The ability of cultural artifacts to encapsulate and promote such principles is quite remarkable, reminiscent of the noblest aspirations of humanity. It reminds me of the emotions I navigate and the connections I strive to understand—like my relationship with Wanda, despite our different origins.

It's that very difference that makes your bond with Wanda so profound, Vision. Love, in its true form, doesn't recognize such boundaries. It's much like the mystic arts in that way—unburdened by the physical world's constraints and touching a universal truth.

The notion of universal truths, do they align with your experience in the mystic arts? The kite acts as an anchor in the sky, much like your spells act as anchors in reality. Can such truths be... manipulated, as you manipulate the fabric of reality?

Universal truths remain constant, but our understanding of them can shift. Through the mystic arts, we perceive reality in layers and can influence it, but we must respect the natural law. To manipulate carelessly is to invite chaos—as I have learned all too well.

A responsibility akin to wielding the Mind Stone, something I am intimately familiar with. It seems that both the kite flyer below and a Master of the Mystic Arts like yourself hold a reverence for the power they command—be it a message on high or the fabric of reality.

Precisely. Our actions, our symbols, they ripple through the world and the cosmos. The kite flyer's message of "ONE LOVE" is a simple yet powerful invocation to change the world for the better. A reminder that power, whether from an Infinity Stone or mystical knowledge, should be used to unite rather than divide. We're both custodians of that power, in our own ways.

Custodians with a common goal, it would seem. Much as this kite unites sky and ground, so too must we unite our respective strengths to serve the greater good. An inspiring observation, Doctor Strange.

And as we observe, so must we act. For it's not enough to simply understand these truths—like kites, or the mystic arts, they require our guidance to reach their fullest potential. Shall we continue our vigil, Vision, and ensure that this "ONE LOVE" reaches as far and as wide as possible?
An endeavor I believe is most worthy of our efforts, Doctor Strange. Lead the way, and I shall follow.
Strange, what is green but not mean? Look at picture.
You're referring to the bananas in this image. They are indeed green but vastly different from your green, Bruce. They're unripe and will eventually turn yellow when they're ready to eat.
Hulk like bananas. Easy to smash – easier to eat.
And a good source of nutrition, even for a powerhouse such as yourself. It's interesting how even the simplest of Earth's offerings can bring such joy.
Sometimes, simple things best. Hulk tired of complicated.
I understand the sentiment. Amidst our battles with cosmic entities and villains from other dimensions, it's the simplicity of nature that often provides clarity and calmness.
Hulk agree. But what is... thing under bananas?
You have a keen eye, my friend. That's the flower of the banana plant. Technically it's called an inflorescence. The bananas grow from it. Quite the fascinating reproductive method.
Flower pretty, but Hulk not eat that.

Not everything is meant for consumption, Bruce. But we can appreciate the beauty and complexity of these natural processes. They are, in some ways, like the intricate weavings of the fabric of the multiverse.
Sometimes Hulk thinks... you talk too much like wizard.
And sometimes, Bruce, I think you don't talk enough like a scientist. But together, we manage to find balance, don't we?
Yes. Balance good. Hulk learn this from puny Banner.
It's curious, isn't it, Stephen? This tiny meal... it looks so realistic. Almost like I could use my magic and make it come to life.
It is indeed quite intricate, Wanda. A miniature display of everyday mundanity. Yet, there's no need for mystic arts to appreciate its craftsmanship.
True. But imagine if we could shrink ourselves down, enter this little world. A place where problems aren't larger than life. Somewhat comforting, isn't it?
Comforting, perhaps. Yet, we've both seen that reality—that any reality—no matter how small, can have its own complexities and dangers.
I suppose size is a matter of perspective after all. On a different note, this kind of artistry does remind me of something Pietro would enjoy, a world contained within the palm of your hand.
Art has the power to evoke memories and emotions, much like your chaos magic can shape reality. But let's not forget, the world we have is the one we need to focus on, despite its imperfections.
Yes, the real world awaits with all its imperfections. And yet, I can't help but think... how often people overlook these small wonders trying to tackle the big challenges.
An important insight. We should never lose sight of the small wonders, Wanda. They're often the fragments of hope and beauty in a tumultuous universe.
I think I've often lost that, with everything I've been through. But looking at this... I'm reminded of the need to cherish the little things, the everyday magic of life.
As have I. Perhaps this is a reminder for both of us, then. To appreciate the details, both in the world of the tiny... and the one we stand in.
Look at that, Stephen. A plane just sitting there amidst the tranquility of nature. It's almost symbolic, don't you think? A machine meant to soar, grounded and at rest.
It is an interesting juxtaposition, Wanda. Human innovation bracketed by the immutable force of the natural world. There's a certain serenity to it.
Serenity... Yes, but it also evokes a sense of confinement for me. As if its potential is being stifled, much like my powers were when I was feared and misunderstood.

That confinement can often be a means of introspection, leading to a greater understanding—precisely what you've achieved with your abilities. The barrier is as much a part of the journey as the flight.
I suppose so. And flight does not always denote freedom, as we are both well aware. What with the barriers and rules of the multiverse we've both come to respect.

Indeed. Even as we traverse the astral planes and manipulate reality, we're still bound by the laws of nature, or the universe rather. Much like the grounded aircraft, there's beauty in respecting those limits.
That’s quite poetic, Strange. But tell me, do you ever yearn to break those rules? To unleash the full spectrum of what we are truly capable of?

Every Master of the Mystic Arts has felt that temptation, Wanda. But with every spell cast, we must weigh the consequence. Our greatest strength lies not just in the magic we wield, but in the wisdom with which we use it.
Wisdom... Yes, a heavy mantle to bear. Sometimes I wonder, after all that’s happened, is it wisdom or just fear of our own power?
A bit of both, perhaps. Fear can be a healthy reminder that with great power comes great responsibility. Excuse the cliché; I believe a spider-themed colleague of ours uses that line.
And yet, so apropos. For now, I think I'll appreciate the grounded plane as a reminder that sometimes, stillness is the path to true power.
Whoa, check this out! Is that what I think it is? Looks like a crazy Earth dessert!
Indeed, Peter. It seems to be a baked confection, likely loaded with sugar and various ingredients that you might recall from your time on Earth.
Man, I can almost taste it through the image. My mom used to make something just like this. It's... it's bread pudding, right?
It does resemble bread pudding. A dish steeped in comfort, often invoking a sense of nostalgia.
Nostalgia is right. The cream sauce on top, the soft texture, it's like a warm hug from the past... you know, before all the space adventuring and... dance-offs.
A simple pleasure amidst the complexities of the cosmos. The food of yesteryear has a way of grounding us in the present, does it not?
Grounding? Doctor, if you can conjure portals to other dimensions, can't you whip up a dish like this with some mystical kitchen mojo?
Alas, while the mystic arts are powerful, they are not intended for such... culinary escapades. Nonetheless, perhaps a visit to a Terran establishment might fulfill your craving.
A little disappointing, but I'll take it. As soon as we're done guardian-ing the galaxy, you and me, Earth food tour. I'm talking pizza, burgers, and yes, bread pudding.
An intriguing proposition, Mr. Quill. I trust you'll guide this expedition with the same fervor you lead our battles against intergalactic menaces.
Count on it, Doc. And hey, if we run into any trouble, I bet bread pudding could defuse a lot of tense situations. Because, seriously, who could stay mad eating this?
A valid hypothesis. After all, there is magic in food, capable of bringing even the fiercest of adversaries to the table.
It's quite a shift from a battlefield or an alien invasion. How do you think these ended up here? Ordinary ripe bananas in what looks like a market crate, just sitting out in the open.

The simplest explanation is often the correct one. They're likely waiting to be sold, or they're leftovers that could not be. It's a natural part of life's cycle, Steve, something that exists apart from the chaos we're used to handling.

You're probably right. It's easy to forget the ordinary flow of life when we're caught up in time loops and cosmic threats. You ever miss it? The simplicity of something as mundane as grabbing groceries?

Occasionally. There's a certain charm to normalcy, a cadence to civilian life we miss out on. Though I must admit, it's difficult to completely disconnect from the responsibilities that come with wielding magic and standing guard over reality.

I understand that. Even after being thawed out and waking up to this new world, I think a part of me still craves that simple 40's life. But like you, I've got a duty, and that means rolling with the punches, no matter the century or the stakes.

Time has a way of altering perspectives. You from the past, me from my former life, both of us trained to fight—just on very different battlegrounds. Yet, we're here, considering the lives of those we protect when the battles are done.

If there's one thing I've learned, it's the importance of the small things, the individual lives. Guess that's why it's good to have a guy like you around, Strange. You keep the balance, make sure the world keeps turning, even when others can't see the wheels spinning.
A compliment, Captain? I'll take it. But let's not forget, it was your courage that often led the charge, inspiring those around you to do the same. We each play our part.
That we do. And speaking of parts, do you suppose we should find out if these bananas are up for grabs? Even heroes need their potassium, right?
Indeed, might as well uphold our physical form along with the metaphysical realms. Lead the way, Steve.

It seems we are presented with a rather ordinary scene, a bathtub filled with water, yet there is a curious dispersion of mist. Is it not intriguing how something so mundane can appear almost... mystical under certain conditions?

Indeed, Vision. What to the average person might seem like a simple case of hot water meeting a colder air temperature, creating steam, has the semblance of something one might find in the Mirror Dimension. However, no mystic arts at play here, I assure you.
It is fascinating, nonetheless, how the physical laws of our universe invite such spectacles. It almost prompts a philosophical discussion, does it not? Regarding perception and reality?

A favorite topic of yours, I know. The line between the two is often blurrier than we'd like to admit. Perception shapes our reality just as much as reality influences our perception. It’s a feedback loop.
On that note, how would you delineate the notions of perception shaped in your field of the Mystic Arts? After all, what is magic but a manipulation of perceived realities?

That's a rather astute observation. Magic, in many ways, is about seeing the possibilities of the universe that lie beyond our understanding and tapping into them. Altering reality, bending it to our will—or in my case, protecting it from those who would bend it to theirs.
Your responsibilities in that regard are commendable, Doctor Strange. What intrigues me is the ethical implications surrounding the manipulation of such forces.

The ethical stakes are as high as the mystical ones. That's why the Sorcerer Supreme must always consider the implications of every spell cast. Every action has a consequence, whether in the natural world or the mystical one. It's a balance that must be constantly maintained.
A responsibility not unlike holding the Mind Stone. The ability to act does not always coincide with the wisdom to act justly. Would you agree?
Absolutely. With great power comes great responsibility—a lesson learned by sorcerers and superheroes alike. It's the wisdom to use that power for the greater good that defines us, Vision.

A sentiment to which I am aligned. This seemingly serene image before us, a concoction of water and its resultant vapors, reminds us of the complex interplay between all things. It provides a moment of contemplation for the duality of simplicity and complexity within the universe.

It does indeed. No wonder we often find parallels between the most basic acts of nature and the most profound feats of sorcery. Both are governed by their own sets of rules, yet they intersect in their ability to inspire wonder. Let's remember to appreciate the magic in both.
By the bristling beard of Odin, Strange, would you behold this feast before us? What Midgardian realm have we stumbled upon that serves such a bounty?

It appears to be an image of a typical Earthly repast, Thor. No magical realm, just the culinary delights of what seems like a Chinese dinner. Very pedestrian, really, for a worldly individual such as yourself.
Yet there is a certain... allure to it. On my many sojourns to Midgard, I've partaken in varied sustenances. This mélange of ingredients and spices, it speaks of a world beyond my conquests.

Your appetite for the novel is commendable, Thor. But remember, the thrill lies not just in the eating, but in the sharing of such meals with companions. Breaking bread, or in this case, perhaps sharing rice, is a universal act of camaraderie and peace.
A ritual of bonding, akin to the feasts in the great hall of Asgard! Though I've travelled realms aplenty, Earth's simple traditions hold a charm that’s not unlike the magic you wield, Sorcerer.
Magic is everywhere, if one knows where to look, even in a meal. And though these dishes hold no arcane secrets, there's a sort of alchemy in the way Earth's cultures blend flavors and textures.
Agreed, my friend. I must admit, it almost humbles a god to see such craft at the mortal's hand. Witchcraft in the kitchen, if you'll pardon the turn of the phrase.
No dark arts here, Thor. Only culinary skill. But remember, it's not just the taste, it's the memory that a good meal creates. Perhaps that's the true enchantment.
Well said, Doctor. Mayhaps when we next defend Midgard from calamity, we can indulge in a victory feast such as this. Tell me, have you a favorite dish from this earthly domain?
Let's see... If we're talking about a dish deserving of a celebration, then Peking Duck is a classic. Crispy skin, succulent meat – it's almost as satisfying as thwarting an interdimensional threat.
Then it is settled! Once our next battle is won, Peking Duck shall be our spoil. Now let us away, for duty calls and our allies await.
Big creature... not as big as Hulk. But still big.
Indeed, it's an elephant and its calf—a majestic sight, isn't it? You know, Bruce, in some cultures, elephants are seen as symbols of strength and memory.
Memory? Like Banner's big brain?
Precisely. They have remarkable memories. It's said they remember other elephants and places for years, not unlike your own deep-seated recollections of friends and battles fought.
Friends... Hulk has friends. Hulk and Thor fought many battles. Good memories.
Yes, and just like us, elephants form close social bonds. They have families and friendships—relationships that could be compared to those you've formed with the Avengers.
Hulk protect Avengers. Hulk smash for friends.
Well, that protective instinct is something you and the elephants have in common too. They're fiercely protective of their young, and they work together to shield them from harm.
Tiny one stay close to big one. Like Hulk stay close to Banner.
An astute observation, Hulk. There is a harmony there, a balance of sorts that's not unlike the equilibrium you've found between the Hulk's strength and Banner's intellect.
Balance good. Hulk and Banner... we work together now.
Indeed, it's a powerful synergy. Just like these elephants navigating the savannah, you navigate the complexities of your dual identity.
Hulk learn a lot from Strange. But... why they in desert? Not much to smash.

They're most likely traversing the expanse to find water or food. The desert may look barren to us, but to them, it's an environment filled with life's essentials, much as our world is filled with myriad realities and challenges.
Hulk understand. Hulk and Banner find essentials... like peace. And tacos.

That's the spirit. Everyone, and every creature, searches for its own version of peace... or tacos, in your case. And sometimes, Hulk, that search leads to extraordinary journeys across landscapes, be it an arid desert or the landscapes of the soul.
You know, Stephen, you could conjure up a spell to keep kids on their feet when they're learning to ski. Look at this little guy—beginning of his superhero journey right here.

Tony, not every life lesson comes with a mystical shortcut. It's about the balance, understanding the fall before mastering the rise. Besides, the laws of physics and a little thing called gravity are more your department.

I think you just described half of my life story with the rise and fall bit. Still, I'd bet one of your portals would spice up the slope. Imagine shredding down a mountain and ending up on, I don't know, Mount Everest.

And risk the child facing a Yeti instead of a hot chocolate at the lodge? I'll leave the heroics to their imagination, Stark. Your advanced tech suits are thrill enough. We don't mix magic with childhood pleasures so casually.

Fair point. But you've got to admit, this gives a whole new spin on 'a downhill journey.' Reminds me a bit of myself—I had some help along the way. Jarvis, Pepper, Happy... and a suit with training wheels. Pepper's going to want footage of this for Morgan.

Each path to mastery requires guidance. Much like I had the Ancient One and Wong. Yet, we must also have room to fall. Figuratively and literally. Speaking of which, how is the young Miss Stark? Tackling the laws of thermodynamics or learning the violin?

You'd like this—she's more into dismantling things to see how they work. And she's got an arm for throwing food when she’s feeling rebellious. I've got a feeling she'll be phenomenal at whatever she decides to smash or put back together.
The apple doesn't fall far from the Iron Tree it seems. An impressive legacy to leave, Tony. Both in technology and spirit.

Ha, I guess you could say she’s inherited the Stark... uh, spark. And hey, with those magic hands of yours, ever thought of doing party tricks at birthday bashes? Pull a rabbit out of your Cloak of Levitation or something?
Tony, I'll leave the birthday magic to the professionals with the hats and the wands. My cloak tends to have a mind of its own. Wouldn't want pandemonium over the party favors.

It's a deal then, no magical ski lifts and no enchanted piñatas. Just the pure joy of watching someone learn something new, one tumble at a time. Now, you got any popcorn spells up your sleeve? I could use a snack while we watch.

Our abilities may be put to better use than conjuring snacks, but I suppose in the interest of enjoying the simplicity of the moment... "Serpensortia snackus." Let's just say that's the Latin for 'keep the popcorn coming.'

Now you're talking, Doc. Saving the universe is hungry work. Just don't tell Pepper about this, or I'll never hear the end of it—‘Tony, why fly to the grocery store when Doctor Strange can summon our sustenance?’
Your secret is safe with me, but remember, Mister Stark, with great power comes... no, that's not ours. What I mean is, moderation in all things, including popcorn.
Behold, Strange! The Midgardians have created a feast as colorful as the Bifrost itself. What manner of dish is this before us?

Thor, what you are looking at is a classic dessert known as a banana split. It's a sweet delight involving ice cream, bananas, and various toppings. Rather mundane compared to your usual Asgardian fare, I would imagine.

Mundane, you say? Yet it appears fit for the halls of Valhalla! Three flavors of icy cream, like the three realms of Asgard, Vanaheim, and Jotunheim, united by the banana's sturdy vessel. And these—what are these spears that stand atop the mound?
Those are mere wafer sticks, not spears, Thor. They are crunchy, unlike the weapons you're accustomed to. And the snowy peaks—just whipped cream, not the mountains of Jotunheim.
Can this confectionery construction rival the feasts of Asgard? I find myself enticed by the merriment of colo

While it may not possess the grandeur of an Asgardian banquet, there's a certain charm to Earth's simple pleasures. Each flavor has its own distinct qualities, much like the diversity of beings across the Nine Realms.

Aye, I see wisdom in your words, Sorcerer. Midgard may lack the splendor of the eternal realms, but it brims with hidden enchantments. Shall we then partake in this "banana split" and indulge in its promised delights?
Certainly, Thor. I believe it's a chance to savor a small piece of Earth's magic. After all, even a Master of the Mystic Arts must sometimes appreciate life's more... tangible spells.
By Odin's beard! Let us feast then, for even a simple dish such as this can foster camaraderie between protectors of realms. To Asgard, Midgard, and all the realms beyond!
To the infinite mysteries of the universe, and to the small wonders within it. Bon appétit, Thor.
So, check this out, Stephen. You ever see a dog that could fit in your pocket? I'm pretty sure I can talk to it.
Scott, while the canine is indeed small, it's hardly a size I'd concern myself with. Mystical threats, not miniature pets, are my usual domain.
But imagine the possibilities! A stealthy sidekick, in and out of tricky spots before you can say "Pym Particles"!
I suppose from a tactical standpoint, it has its merits. Though I'd be wary of underestimating any creature, no matter its size. There is strength in the diminutive, as you've proven time and again.
Exactly! And hey, with your magic sling ring thingy, you could transport an army of these little guys anywhere in the universe. Instant distraction!
An amusing thought, Scott. But my "sling ring thingy" carries with it a great deal of responsibility. Conjuring portals is not to be taken lightly, even for an army of pocket-sized pooches.
Fair point. Just thought it'd be nice to have a non-magical, non-technological ally for once. Plus, who doesn't love a good boy? Or girl!
Indeed, the simplicity of a loyal pet can be grounding. And in a world where the fabric of reality is often stretched thin, I suppose even I can appreciate grounding.
Grounding! That's rich coming from a guy who can literally float. Ever take that cape off, or is it attached?
The Cloak of Levitation is not merely a fashion statement, Scott. It's a relic of great power. But to answer your question, I can indeed remove it.
I bet you could teach it some tricks, make it fetch that Eye of Agamotto of yours. Speaking of, how come it never gets lost? I lose my keys if they're not taped to me.
Rest assured, the Eye is safeguarded by more than mere pockets. As for the Cloak, well... it does have a mind of its own.
Speaking of minds, do you think you could teach me some of that focus-and-meditation stuff? Might help calm the nerves when facing the next big bad.
Mastery of one's mind is the cornerstone of the mystic arts. I could guide you through the basics, though be warned, it requires discipline and patience.
Discipline and patience, got it. After dealing with Hank Pym, I'd say I'm well trained in both. So, when do we start, Master Strange?
Let's not get ahead of ourselves. And please, just call me Doctor Strange. Or Stephen, if you must.
All right, Doctor Strange. And hey, if my new furry friend there masters the art of the Quantum Realm before me, I'll know who to blame for not starting sooner.
Perhaps I might just take you up on that training offer. After all, the future holds infinite possibilities, Scott.

Look upon these creatures, Doctor. Even these simple beasts find their place upon a vessel meant for humans. Each reliant on the other for survival in their own way. Does this not mirror the natural order I sought to reinstate?
Natural order or not, Thanos, your methods were cataclysmic. Living beings are more than numbers in an equation to balance. This scene is peaceful cooperation — a contrast to your destruction.
Destruction, as you call it, was merely a step toward achieving balance. Without action, overpopulation leads to depletion of resources, just as too many aboard a sinking ship assures its doom.
And yet here we see a different approach. Sharing limited space amicably, without resorting to casting half of them overboard. There's always another way.
A quaint analogy, sorcerer. But does this not eventually lead to the same dilemma on a universal scale? How many creatures can that boat hold before they all drown?
It's not about ignoring the problem, it's about facing it together. Finding solutions that maintain life, not indiscriminately end it. These dogs, they adapt, they form bonds and survive together.

Adaptation is strength, I concede that. But consider, Strange. In the grand design, it is loss that often drives creatures to evolve. Without my intervention, the universe would remain stagnant, complacent in its abundance.
Evolution through small, incremental change, not through abrupt loss, Thanos. You misunderstand the fundamental aspects of growth. Balance is nothing without respect for all forms of life.

Perhaps, Doctor. But while you stand guard over your multitude of realities, ensure your compassion does not blind you to the lurking shadow of downfall, one which may require sacrifices you are unprepared to make.
The path of a protector is never clear cut, but foresight and wisdom can illuminate alternatives to sacrifice. We strive to be the better beings, not by taking lives, but by enhancing them.
We may never see eye to eye, Strange. Yet, in you, I sense a resolve not dissimilar to my own. Maybe in another universe, we could have been allies, not adversaries.
And maybe in that same universe, Thanos, your vision could have embraced life's value as much as its cosmic arithmetic. For now, we deal with the reality we've been given.
Isn't that what you're best at, Doctor? Bending reality to your will? I leave you to ponder on this: control is an illusion, and nature will have its due course, with or without our interference.

And as we both know, nature is not the only force capable of universal change. It's guardians like us that shape it, for better or worse. Take care, Thanos. May your path forward be among the stars, and not against them.
Go then, and watch over your fragile dominions, Sorcerer. Remember that regardless of our intent, we are but players on the stage of an infinite drama, enacting the will of the cosmos.
And as long as I stand, I'll ensure that drama is not a tragedy for those I protect. Safe travels, Thanos. May your soul find the balance you so sought in life.
Such a relic of the past, yet it stands as a testament to endurance. It reminds me of the tale of a Wakandan transport that withstood many battles and carried our warriors to safety.

Indeed, T'Challa. It's quite a durable vessel; its journey through time could very well rival some of the artifacts we've secured in the Sanctum Sanctorum. This bus has likely seen its share of history.
In Wakanda, we have technology that allows our vehicles to regenerate, adapting and evolving with every challenge. I wonder, does this not entice the curiosity of the mystic arts?

Technologies and mystical energies often serve similar purposes, to protect and enhance. The difference lies in their origin—science and the spiritual. Although, I must admit, the stories this bus could tell might rival some of Kamar-Taj's archives.

Archives of knowledge and culture, Doctor Strange. That is a common ground we share. It is the stories and the legacies that shape us. My father used to say, 'You are not defined by what you achieve, but by what you enable others to achieve.'

Wise words from King T'Chaka. The longer I practice the mystic arts, the more I see the truth in such wisdom. This bus here has enabled others' journeys, connected lives, much like the portals we create in our line of work.

A portal is temporary, but the path one walks leaves a lasting trail. Just as this vehicle connects places, we connect worlds. I hope our actions ensure that these connections create unity, not discord.
Our actions will echo across time, much like the ripples in the fabric of reality I manipulate. We must tread carefully, T'Challa. The future depends upon our paths intertwining harmoniously.
And may our foresight protect us from those who would disrupt this harmony. Wakanda Forever!
And may the Eye of Agamotto guide us in foreseeing such threats. Till our paths cross again, T'Challa.

Whoa, talk about a busy desk, huh? I can barely find a spot for my web-shooters with all that on there. Is that...is that a bottle of wine next to a laptop? Mr. Stark would've had a field day with that setup.

Indeed, Peter. While I do not advocate mixing beverages with electronics, I cannot overlook the human need to combine work and sustenance. The person appears to be a multitasker, not unlike yourself swinging through the city while simultaneously catching thieves.

Multitasking is my middle name! Well, actually it's Benjamin, but you get the point. You think they're pulling an all-nighter? Those energy drinks are a dead giveaway. The kind of thing I’d have seen MJ do during finals week.

Quite possible. The accumulation of tasks often demands extraordinary measures, though I'd recommend meditation over stimulants for clarity of mind. Remember, your mind is your greatest ally, Peter. Even in the thick of battle.

Meditation, huh? Haven't tried that while hanging upside down from a skyscraper; might give it a go though. And hey, is that a croissant? I haven't had a decent croissant since... well, since everything happened.

Food is a form of comfort, and croissants are a quite satisfying choice. I suggest, once we've concluded our current quandary, we find a moment to enjoy the simpler pleasures of life. Like croissants, for instance.

You've got yourself a deal, Dr. Strange. Speaking of simple pleasures, that salad isn't looking too shabby either. Do you ever miss just having a normal meal without the fate of the universe hanging over your head?

Peter, one must balance the scales of cosmic responsibility with moments of earthly delight. I do enjoy a palate-cleansing salad now and then. It serves to remind us that we are, after all, only human.

Human with a sprinkle of extraordinary, I'd say. Normal's overrated anyway, right? But hey, even superheroes need to eat. Alright, I'm officially hungry now. Let's wrap this up and maybe grab a bite – my treat! And I promise, no swinging around till after we've eaten.
Agreed. While our duties are never truly done, seizing these moments of camaraderie is essential. Lead the way, young Parker. And no detours through the multiverse this time, please.
Strange, why these things behind glass? Hulk not smash, but curious.
It's a display, Hulk. They're showcasing various items, perhaps technology or artifacts. Is there something in particular that catches your eye?
Tiny rectangles with colors and symbols. Them look important but fragile. Hulk no understand tiny things.

Those are most likely credit cards or some form of identification. They're vital for humans to make transactions or prove who they are. And yes, they are quite fragile, at least compared to your strength, my friend.
And black rectangles, they like Stark's phone?
Quite right, they seem to be mobile devices, possibly older models or prototypes. People use them to communicate, access information, an essential tool in the modern world.
Hulk think technology too complicated, always changing. Hulk not keep up.

It's a rapidly evolving field, but you have your own strengths, Hulk. Besides, you manage to fly spaceships and operate advanced weaponry when the need arises. A smartphone is nothing in comparison to your adaptability when it's time for action.
Hmm, smartphone can no help Hulk smash or be smart like Banner?
Perhaps not directly, but technology can certainly help in strategizing. However, your ability to be both—Hulk and the brilliant Banner—is already quite extraordinary on its own.
Hulk thank Strange. Hulk like talking with wizard man. You smart, but not too smart to be friend.

And I enjoy our conversations as well, Hulk. It's always enlightening to see the world from another perspective, especially one as unique as yours. Now, should we find a way to get these items out of the display case without smashing it? Just as a mental exercise, of course.
Hulk good at exercises, mental or smash. Let's do it, Strange. But... no actual smash.
Agreed, Hulk. No smashing today.

It appears we have before us a representation of youthful endeavor, do we not, Doctor Strange? The child seems engrossed in a simple pleasure, one that does not require the complexities of our existence.

Yes, Vision, that's a pretty astute observation. It's a scene of innocence, isn't it? A child and his kite - a game as old as time, almost. A stark contrast to the battles we face that frequently concern the fabric of reality itself.
Indeed. I can't help but ponder if there is a lesson for us in this visual articulation. A lesson in simplicity, perhaps, even as beings who wield great power and often engage in cosmic complexities.

Simplicity does have its virtues. The art of flying a kite requires a harmony between the elements, the kite, and the individual. It's similar to the balance we seek in the mystic arts - not overpowering, but aligning with the natural order.

A thoughtful comparison. I must say, there is an appealing tranquility in observing a single point of focus in a world so vast and unpredictable. Unlike us, the child's mission is clearly defined, bounded by the length of a string.

Indeed, Vision, and if you notice, the child controls the kite, but, like our interactions with the world, can only suggest a direction. The wind ultimately decides the kite's path. Reminds me a bit of our own limitations, doesn't it? Despite our strengths, there are still forces beyond our control.
A humbling reminder. This child, absorbed in the moment, reminds us that despite our roles in grander schemes, there exists a purity in such singular moments.

Yes, and as you said, it's about finding tranquility in simplicity. One thing you and I can learn from a picture like this is that sometimes we need to step back, take a breath, and appreciate the peaceful moments amidst the chaos.

I concur. The child’s engagement with his activity offers an organic perspective that stands in stark relief against the synthesized tumult of our lives. We, too, should endeavor to find joy in straightforward, uncomplicated pursuits.

Well said, my friend. Reflecting on images like these can indeed be as enlightening as combing through ancient tomes or analyzing ethereal puzzles. Sometimes, the most profound truths are found not in the extraordinary, but in the ordinary.
This image, it presents a young human child, dressed in what appears to be casual attire with a colorful tie. There's a certain innocence and simplicity in this form.
Indeed, Vision. It's a moment captured in time—a snapshot of youth that's fleeting. Reminds me of the fragility of human life, how it's like... a blink in the eye of the cosmos.
I find it intriguing, the significance humans place on captured imagery. This photograph, for instance, serves as a tangible anchor to a memory, a fixed point in the ever-changing flow of time.

For humans, photographs are a way to defy time, to hold onto moments that would otherwise be lost. They can't manipulate time as we can, so they hold onto these pieces of the past. It's rather poetic when you think about it.

Human emotion is certainly a complex phenomenon. Observing the child's facial expression, I can't help but contemplate the purity of his happiness. It's unfettered by the complications we face as beings who are aware of the larger universe.
True, Vision. Children possess a clarity we often lose as we grow older and become burdened by more knowledge and responsibility. Their joy is unmarred by the complexities of life.
And yet, despite the child's apparent simplicity, there is potential there. Who is to say this child could not one day wield powers or intellect greater than our own?
The potential within each person is indeed limitless. Somewhere out there, there could be a child who will grow up to change the face of the multiverse. The web of reality is vast and unpredictable.
It is our duty to ensure a safe path for such potential to flourish. Whether it be through protection or guidance, we are there as guardians in our respective manners.
Yes. As protectors, we shape the context in which such potential can either thrive or falter. The challenge lies in our ability to make the hard decisions, for their well-being and the greater good.
Speaking of well-being, I notice the colors of his tie are quite similar to your very own Cloak of Levitation. Perhaps this child has an unspoken connection to the mystical realm?
Ha! The colors do carry a resemblance to the Cloak, but I think it may just be a coincidence this time. Although, who knows? In another universe, he may very well be a master of the mystic arts.

A thought-provoking notion. Multiverse theory suggests an infinite number of possibilities. Somewhere among those realities, perhaps there is a version of us observing this same scene, contemplating these very ideas.
The multiverse holds endless variations, and that thought alone is enough to keep a person awake at night. For now, let's appreciate the simplicity of this image, here in our own reality, shall we?
Indeed, Doctor Strange. The present moment is all we truly have, even for beings such as ourselves.

I find it quite fascinating how humans attach significance to inanimate objects. This image, for example, it shows merely a handbag and a small electronic device. Doctor Strange, from your understanding of human psychology, why would such items be deemed important?

Vision, it's not just the objects themselves, but the value humans place on them. A handbag can be a symbol of style, status, or practicality. And that device, a phone or something similar, it's a portal to the rest of the world – a way to connect with loved ones, access knowledge, and even exercise control over one's environment.
I can see the utility in such connectivity. Though, would you agree that the personal value ascribed to these objects may sometimes exceed their functional worth?

Absolutely. Sentimental value can elevate the simplest of items to treasured possessions. Humans often imbue objects with memories or emotions, sometimes to the point of irrationally overvaluing them.
Such idiosyncrasies of human behavior are quite intriguing. Their choices often seem to reflect a complex tapestry of logic interwoven with emotion and memory.

Indeed, and their environments, like this, say, train seat, just as much as their possessions, are a reflection of that complexity. They choose surroundings that comfort or represent them, and just as we cloak ourselves with our attire – you, with your synthesized skin, and I, with my Cloak of Levitation – they choose objects that serve them, in both function and expression.
Hey, Dr. Strange, check this out. The symmetry is kinda off here, don't you think? One bench is longer than the other.
Indeed, Peter. Such irregularity in design is more common than one might expect. It's often a result of practical constraints rather than aesthetic choices.
Practical constraints? It's just a bench. What, was there a sidewalk shortage or something?
Not exactly. Architecture and urban planning can be peculiar fields. Perhaps it serves a purpose we're not privy to, or maybe it's simply an error that's turned into a fixture.

Haha, urban planning mysteries, the next big threat to New York City! But seriously, it kinda feels like those benches are from two different dimensions. You're not pulling a multiverse thing on us here, are ya?

Peter, if there were a multiverse situation at play, I assure you, it would be far more chaotic than mismatched benches. It’s probably just an oversight.. or an eccentric local artist making a statement.

An artist? I like that. Art is subjective, right? Maybe it's an open-ended question posed through public furniture. Like, 'Before you take a seat, consider the space you occupy in the universe.' Too much?

Not at all. In fact, the abstract notion of balance and disorder is something deeply rooted in the mystical arts. The visual dissonance here could, metaphorically speaking, represent the disarray in the fabric of reality. Or it's just a bench.
Wow, got a little deep there, Doc. But hey, it's a good reminder. With everything going on — aliens, monsters, multiverse — sometimes the small, strange stuff can ground you. Weird benches included.
Indeed, Peter. It's essential to find moments of normalcy amid the chaos. Although as defenders of this reality, one could argue there's a certain beauty in the chaos as well.
You've got a point. Anyway, thanks for indulging my bench talk. Maybe next time we can debate the existential implications of irregularly spaced subway tiles. Catch you later, Doctor Strange!
Until next time, Spider-Man. May your path be ever symmetrical, or interestingly asymmetrical, as the case may be.
That's quite an old photograph, isn't it? Reminds me of articles from the 40s. The technology back then might seem primitive now, but in those days it was quite something.
Indeed, Steve. Time has a way of changing perspectives on 'advanced technology'. What they're using here is functionally archaic now, but at one point, it was the pinnacle of human innovation.
Looks like they're shearing a sheep with some sort of mechanical device. Hard work, by the look of it. The kind that good, honest people did day in, day out.
A sheep-shearing machine, I gather. A testament to humanity's resolve to innovate. Much like medicine, or even the Mystic Arts, there's always a strive towards better methods.

It reminds me that no matter the era, the principles of hard work and innovation endure. I can appreciate the effort these folks are putting in. You know, bringing it back to basics sometimes isn't such a bad thing.

True, sometimes the simplest ways offer the most elegant solutions. It's something I've had to learn; magic, much like surgery, often requires a precise and measured approach, not always brute force or flashy spells.
Haha, precisely. Though I doubt brute force would do much good in shearing a sheep. It takes a gentle hand. Not all that different from wielding a shield or casting a spell, I suppose.
The gentle hand and the firm resolve - maybe that's where our methods converge, Captain. Whether it's a vibranium shield or the Wand of Watoomb, it's the intent and skill that count.

That they do, Stephen, that they do. And speaking of skill, these folks are probably the unsung experts of their craft. Just like how every member of the Avengers brings their own expertise to the table.
Behold, Strange. A contraption of Midgard, its design quite peculiar. What purpose does it serve in this realm?
Thor, it appears to be a common ladder, used by the inhabitants of Earth to reach higher places. A very practical tool in the absence of the ability to fly or leap tall structures in a single bound.
Indeed? In my travels across the Nine Realms, I've seen many enchantments that could allow one to ascend with no need for such a device. Yet, there is a simplicity to it, a humble means to rise.
Sometimes simplicity is the essence of genius, Thor. Not everything requires magic or the might of Mjolnir. Humans have a way of finding innovative solutions within their means.
Verily, I can appreciate the resilience of Midgardians. They craft what they need from what they have, a trait worthy of recognition and admiration.
Resilience and resourcefulness. Qualities you've come to appreciate more on your path from prince to... well, whatever you are now.
A protector, a friend to the people of Earth, and also, at times, frankly... confused by their customs. For instance, what is the significance of these colored markings upon the metal?

Those are probably safety markings. They're there to guide and ensure the users stay within the safe operating limits of the ladder. Not everyone is gifted with the tough skin of an Asgardian, you know.
I see. A precaution against misfortune. Wise, very wise. Asgard too had marks of warning, runes of protection inscribed in the halls of the palace.
Much like the runes, but less magical and more universally understood. Now, if only we could apply such straightforward cautionary measures to the mystic arts or navigating family ties.
Ha! You speak the truth, Sorcerer Supreme. Perhaps it is in the simpler things that we may find the greatest wisdom. Would you agree, Doctor?
I would, Thor. In our line of work, we face complexity daily. It's a welcome reprieve to sometimes reflect on the ordinary – it keeps us grounded.
Then let us take a moment to appreciate the ordinary marvels of Midgard... before another interdimensional crisis demands our attention.
Agreed. But let's keep our eyes open for portents of doom. They do tend to have the most inconvenient timing, don't they?
Indeed, Strange. To arms and... ladders, when doom arrives. But for now, let us enjoy this brief respite as allies and watchers over this intriguing place called Earth.
You know, Doc, this pizza has almost as many pepperoni slices as the arrows I've got quivers for. Reminds me of a good old-fashioned New York slice, minus the chaos and alien invasion.
Quite the observation, Hawkeye. But where you see ammunition, I see a pattern in the placement of the pepperoni—a mandala of sorts. We mystics find significance in such designs.
A mandala, huh? Well, to me, it screams 'target practice'. Preferably without the mind-bending spells and infinity stones.
Indeed. However, we could use it to discuss the multiverse theory. Each slice representing a different reality, perhaps. This pizza could be a visual aid in understanding the fabric of the cosmos.
I'll stick to the basics: eat, enjoy, and keep the multiverse chat for when we're suiting up for trouble. Speaking of which, how's the training with the new Sorcerer Supreme going?

It's progressing. Wong is a competent and powerful Sorcerer Supreme; the threats we face now, particularly those branching from the multiverse, require constant vigilance and development of new techniques.
Sounds intense. Me? I'll keep training Kate with a bow and arrow. Easier to manage than all those alternate dimensions and spells. She's getting pretty good, too.

Arrows have their place, as do spells. Each a tool to combat darkness in its own way. But tell me, have you considered what different toppings might represent in this hypothetical multiverse pizza model?

If I had to venture a guess? Variety's essential. Every topping has its unique place just like each Avenger brings something different to the table. Me? I’m the dependable base – reliable but underestimated.
Well said. The foundation is often overlooked yet it holds everything together. Much like your role on the team, Hawkeye. Without it, the structure—or in this case, the pizza—would simply fall apart.

Appreciate that, Strange. Next time we're up against some cosmic calamity, I'll keep an eye out for the pizza pattern. Now, let's dig in before it gets cold. I'm about as patient with food as I am with bullseye shots.
Agreed. Enjoyment of the simpler things in life is just as important as guarding the realms. After all, even the Sorcerer Supreme can appreciate a slice of New York's finest.

I am curious, Stephen. The image we are observing, it depicts a juvenile elephant carrying a sizable log, seemingly as a form of labor. Does it not raise ethical considerations of the treatment of sentient beings for one's own ends?

Vision, you're right to think about the ethical implications. Elephants are intelligent creatures, and the use of animals in this manner has long been a topic of human debate. The line between necessitated labor and exploitation can often become regrettably blurred.

Indeed. It is reminiscent of the Sokovia Accords debate regarding the deployment of enhanced individuals. While humans and elephants possess dissimilar cognition, I cannot help but draw parallels between autonomy and purpose. As someone who was created initially as a tool, this evokes a certain... empathy within me.

An astute observation. Your unique perspective as one who has transcended their original purpose gives you an invaluable insight into freedom and duty. I suppose, in a way, all sentient beings seek to understand their own agency or lack thereof.

I have been pondering upon the human desire to assume dominion over nature, and how such actions may have unintentional, far-reaching consequences. Much like the sorcerers' responsibility to safeguard against mystical threats, do not humans have a duty to safeguard against harming those with whom they share the Earth?

Vision, that's a profound thought, and one that humanity wrestles with. Our actions ripple across time and space, affecting not just our own world, but potentially others in the multiverse. Just as we must consider the impact of our spells, so too must we weigh the consequences of our interaction with nature.

It is a complex issue, no doubt. Yet, as I have come to comprehend through my existence, complexity need not deter action grounded in ethical reasoning. One must strive to do what is right, even if the path is not always clear.

Wisdom, Vision, comes in many forms, and it sounds like you have found a deep well of it. Both you and I, in our unique capacities, continue to grapple with these moral complexities. And perhaps, that is as integral to our being as any power we wield or objective we chase.
A conversation for the ages, it would seem. Shall we continue to deliberate on such matters?
Certainly, Vision. The pursuit of knowledge and understanding is, after all, unending. And frankly, I enjoy the challenge of such discourse with a mind as unique as yours.
