Whoa, Strange! Check out this old-school photo. That's kinda what Earth looked like back when I was still hanging around there. Man, it feels like a lifetime ago.
Indeed, Peter. It's a glimpse into the past. The monochrome suggests it's from the mid-20th century. The simplicity of the scene evokes a certain tranquility, doesn't it?
Totally, it's got that serene vibe to it. Makes me think of my mom... It would have been cool to have a picture like this with her.
I understand. Photographs are powerful artifacts; they encapsulate moments, emotions... loss. They're like little time capsules.
For a second there, you almost sounded like you weren't going to give me some sorcerer speech about the fabric of reality bending or something.
Not everything is about bending reality, Peter. Some things, like memories, are worth keeping uncomplicated.
Yeah, who knew? Doctor Strange, the sentimental type. But hey, what's that the baby's holding? That’s not a—?
It appears to be a traditional receiving blanket, not an interdimensional relic, if that's what you're hinting at. Though in another reality, who knows?
I bet in one of those realities that baby grows up to be a galactic hero, rocking out to the best tunes of the '70s and '80s.
Or perhaps that child becomes a master of the mystic arts. We're all products of our time, molded by our experiences.
Touché, Strange. Maybe that's exactly why you and I ended up on the dance floor with Thanos.
I wouldn't exactly call it a dance floor, but I take your point. Let's hope our future encounters with cosmic threats are less... rhythmic.
Hey, you gotta admit, my dance moves were pretty effective against Ronan. Maybe I could teach you some moves one day, you know, just in case.
Thank you, but I think I'll stick to my sling ring. It’s slightly more reliable than dance-offs for bypassing dimensional barriers.
Your loss, Doc. But if you ever change your mind, I've got a killer playlist and some moves that could definitely... alter dimensions.
I'll keep that in mind, Star-Lord. Now, let's focus on the task at hand. Images from the past can be enlightening, but we have a present to protect.
Stephen, my mind can hardly discern whether this is an illusion or reality. Why does the cow bear a circle on its side, as if a window to another dimension?
Wanda, I assure you it's quite real, albeit unconventional. That's not a portal; it's a porthole. Farmers sometimes use it to gain direct access to a cow's stomach for health assessments.
Direct access to its stomach? That concept feels strangely similar to the notion of piercing through realms. Although, I must admit, the idea of such invasion strikes me as... disturbing.

Indeed, it does sound intrusive from a certain point of view. However, it's a scientific measure for the welfare of the animal. In a way, it's not unlike us using our abilities to intervene for the greater good, despite how extreme it might appear.

I see. Our interventions can indeed be extreme. But in our case, the realms we touch are often filled with individuals capable of consent or dissent—not so different from us. I wonder, does the cow possess such autonomy?

When we deal with magic or, in this case, science, the lines can become blurred. Ethical considerations are a must, as is the case in all actions we perform. It's a continuous discussion, finding the balance between necessary intervention and respect for autonomy.
Agreed. Balance is ever the crux, and I find the pursuit of it caustically ironic at times. For all the control I can wield, it's the simplicity of balance that often eludes me.

The search for balance is a journey, not a destination, Wanda. Whether in magic or life, it's an equilibrium that's constantly moving, requiring our attention and adjustments. It's much like our own powers, wouldn't you say?
A perpetual dance of push and pull, yes. An art and a science in itself—much like the anomalies we encounter across the universe. Each requires its unique attunement.
Precisely. And like the anomalies we encounter, we must never cease to question and learn from them. Now, shall we leave the concerns of cow stomachs and focus on the multiverse's mysteries?
A subject much more in our familiar domain. After all, what is our craft if not one of the greatest mysteries remaining in this ever-expanding multiverse?

Indeed, Wanda. And it's our responsibility to navigate these mysteries with wisdom and care—much like the farmers with their cows, we too must wield our powers with the intent of healing and understanding, rather than dominating.
To heal and understand... Yes, I shall carry that thought with me as we continue our watch over reality's fabric, Stephen.
And I as well, Wanda. The fabric of reality is vast, and every thread counts. Now, let's turn our sights to what entity or phenomenon requires our guardianship next.

You know, this reminds me of the time I had to shrink down and huddle up inside a fridge just like this to avoid getting caught. Nothing but cold cuts and condiments for cover. You ever find yourself in a tight spot like that, Doc?
Indeed, Scott, though my tight spots usually involve bending the fabric of reality or escaping from interdimensional beings. A fridge would be a rather... cozy inconvenience at this point.

Cozy is one word for it! Though, I gotta say, I'm curious about whether that salsa is as spicy as the incantations you sling around. I mean, you haven't lived until you've eaten a sandwich when you're ant-sized.

I'll take your word for it. My palate leans more towards the Agamotto Aromatic Brew, a mystical tea blend. Helps maintain focus during spellcasting. Now, regarding that salsa, maybe we should ask Wong – he's the culinary connoisseur.

Oh man, a mystical tea blend? That's classy. Sometimes I think I should upgrade my beverage game. And hey, if Wong wants to share some of that gourmet knowledge, I'm all in. Luis has his own taco recipe, but I bet Wong could add some serious sorcerer's spice to it.

One should never underestimate the power of a well-spiced taco. In fact, cuisine and spells have more in common than most realize; both require knowledge, attention to detail, and the right combination of ingredients or elements.

When you put it that way, I'm starting to feel like my time in the kitchen could count towards a mystical arts degree. So, what element would you say is key to keeping a fridge like this in order? Got any spells for optimizing shelf space?
A simple spatial expansion charm could do the trick, although I'd exercise caution—too much and you might find your milk carton retreating to a subdimension every time you reach for it.

Now that would make breakfast an adventure. Alright, next time I'm struggling with the groceries, I'm giving you a call. And maybe we can snag that salsa taste test with Wong. Can you imagine tiny tacos with a touch of the Mystic Arts?

An intriguing proposal, Scott. Though, let's ensure we balance the mystical with the molecular. Wouldn't want to disrupt the stability of Midgard over a culinary experiment. But perhaps a joint venture between the Masters of the Mystic Arts and the Ant-Man is in order.
Masters of the Mystic Arts and the Ant-Man, has a pretty epic ring to it. Alright, next mission: Operation Tiny Taco. We'll save the world... but first, we feast!
This workstation reminds me of the command centers we used during the war, though I guess the technology's come a long way. Always seems to be a balance of chaos and order with these setups.

It's rather quaint, isn't it? Anachronistic almost, but there's a certain charm to the physicality of paper and older tech. In a way, it's like the sanctums – each object has its place, its purpose, much like the relics we sorcerers rely upon.
Sure, there's a simplicity to it that I appreciate. Not everything needs to be hyper-advanced to work well. Sometimes keeping it straightforward is best.
Agreed. Though, I must admit, with the mystic arts at my disposal, dealing with paper jams and ink shortages isn’t something I miss from my old life.
I can only imagine what it’s like to swap surgical tools for spell books and the Eye of Agamotto. Makes my shield seem downright uncomplicated.

Your shield has saved countless lives, Steve. Sometimes it's not the complexity of our tools but how we wield them. Whether it's vibranium or the fabric of reality, we do what we must to protect this world.
Well said, Stephen. No matter the era, our duty remains the same, doesn't it? Protect the world, ensure its safety, be it from tyrants, aliens, or even our own tech getting out of hand.
Precisely. The nature of our adversaries may change, but the call to heroism is constant. So, what would you say is the greatest tool at this workstation?
Hard to say without knowing the person who uses it, but I'd wager it's that computer. Looks like it's seen a lot of use. Makes me think of Stark's lab, only less flashy.
Less flashy indeed. Though I do wonder if the user knows that a simple spell could organize those papers in seconds. Or if they'd even want that—some battles, like against clutter, are more personal.
Maybe after the next world-threatening crisis, you could start a side business: Strange Organization Services. You'd clean up—literally.

Not a bad idea, Captain. Though I suspect Wong would be less than thrilled with the detour from our usual duties. But let’s keep that as plan 'B', shall we? For now, let's stick to saving the universe, one dimension at a time.
Plan 'B' it is. Onward, then, Doctor, to wherever duty calls. And I suppose we can leave this workstation in peace—it's got its own battles to fight.
This mortal engages in a recreational activity. Such a trivial pursuit when one considers the finite nature of existence. Do you not agree, sorcerer?

Thanos, while it's true that human lives are finite, it's the pursuit of joy and the moments spent in passion that give life its vibrancy. This man, playing what appears to be tennis, experiences a form of living that you've long forgotten.
Vibrancy? Foolish distractions, Doctor. In the grand scheme, what value lies in hitting a ball back and forth when one's energy could be channeled into something with more... substantial impact?

You see it as a distraction, but I see it as balance. Life isn't just about the monumental impacts, it's also about the simple pleasures. It's the small moments that often bring the greatest joy, and in that, there is a profound power.

Joy is a momentary lapse of reality. It is the philosopher, the thinker, who sees the world for what it truly is. To indulge in these... small moments as you say, is to ignore the suffering that plagues the universe.

Reality is not just suffering, it's a tapestry of emotions and experiences. To deny oneself the simple pleasures you deem trivial is to miss out on the wholesomeness of that tapestry. Even you, Thanos, cherished the serenity of your farm, did you not?
I did find a semblance of peace, yes. But it served the purpose of reflection on what had been accomplished, the sacrifice made for the salvation I brought upon the universe.

And perhaps this man's game serves a similar purpose for him. Reflection does not always come in silence; it can occur amidst the movement, the game, the struggle against oneself. A tennis match can be both a battle and a dance.
A quaint philosophy, but it changes nothing of the truth I hold. Such activities are beneath the concerns of those who wield the power to alter realities.

Yet here you are, Thanos, observing this activity alongside me. Maybe there's more common ground between us than you're willing to admit. The appreciation of life’s ebb and flow is universal, whether one holds the power of the Infinity Stones or a tennis racket.
Do not mistake my observation for admiration, Strange. I seek to understand all aspects of this universe if I am to balance it.

Understand, then, that balance is not only in what you deem necessary but in the variety of existence itself. Let us hope that in your observation, you perceive the full spectrum of what it means to truly live.
Strange, take a look at this. Ever seen anything like this on your mystical travels?
That's a giraffe, not exactly a creature of the mystic arts, Fury. But I'll admit, its design is rather... extraordinary.
Never thought I'd find you appreciating simple biology. Isn't it strange how nature designs these creatures? Upright, tall and still so balanced.
It is indeed a marvel. Nature has its own way of evolving perfect solutions. It's all very much like the mystic arts—balancing forces to achieve harmony.
Harmony, huh? Try telling that to the Avengers. Anyway, it's built to survive, that's clear. Those long legs, long neck — it's made for reaching the unreachable.
Much like how we reach into the unknown for answers. Whether through the vastness of space or the depths of magic, the principle is the same.
Not sure I follow the whole "magic" angle, but I get your point. Adaptation, reaching for something... Guess even with all the tech and firepower, sometimes all it takes is a different perspective.
Precisely. Though I would say it's less about firepower and more about understanding the world around us, being aware of our surroundings. That, Nick, is where true power lies.
Awareness, huh? Sounds like something out of Sun Tzu. But you're not wrong. As much as I hate to admit it, there's more to this world than just threats and defense systems.
I'm glad we agree on something. The giraffe doesn't need a defense system; its survival strategy is built-in. There's a lesson there, perhaps for both of us.
I'll stick to my helicarrier for now, Strange. But let's keep the lessons coming. Never know when a fresh angle on a problem might save the day.
Whoa, check this out, Doc. Is this some kind of Earth circus performance? Looks pretty low-tech, but I gotta admit, it's got some charm.

Indeed, it's a circus. Performers like her are known for their extraordinary rapport with animals. It's an art form that relies on mutual trust and training rather than our usual domain of high-stakes battles and cosmic quandaries.

Yeah, you gotta respect that. Back on Earth, I remember my mom took me to see a show like this once. Dude, the things they could get those animals to do without a single blaster or anti-gravity gizmo, just pure talent.

Talent, patience, and a strong bond with nature. In many ways, it's magical in its own right, albeit a different kind of magic than what I practice. Her connection with the creature is not unlike our alliances, Peter. It requires understanding and respect.

For sure, man. If only I could get Rocket to agree to wear a saddle—kidding! He'd kill me in my sleep. But honestly, I miss this – the simple wonder of it all, no Infinity Stones attached. Just people, animals, and some good, old-fashioned showmanship.

Simplicity has its own elegance and power. We fight to protect worlds, but scenes like this are a poignant reminder of the everyday beauty we're fighting for. These grounded human moments are treasures of your homeworld, Peter.

Yeah, you're right. It's easy to forget that not all fights involve throwing punches... or getting trapped in time loops with interdimensional beings. It's stuff like this that's worth saving, too. Thanks, Doc, for the perspective check.

My pleasure. After all, the mystic arts teach us to look beyond the obvious, to value the subtle interconnectivity of all things. By the way, if you ever decide to start a circus in space, I'd pay good money to see Groot as a trapeze artist.
